What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you put forth a good effort your chinese will develop a lot
I learned more vocabulary, grammar, and worked to improve my pronunciation.
Speaking, listening chinese
more advanced chinese skills
I continued to enhance what I had learned along the CHNS track at Yale. This semester we focused a lot more on Chinese politics, history, culture, and food.
I greatly strengthened my Chinese proficiency and learned new vocabulary to discuss political and social issues

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very good textbook that gives you vocabulary for topics you will likely want to be able to discuss and introduces some interesting chinese history / culture

The organization of this course is a strength. Also I appreciate how the course exposes students to all elements of a foreign language (speaking, writing, reading, etc.). Students are constantly taking in material from different inputs, and this allows their Chinese level to improve rapidly. Also, the dialogue topics were really interesting and helped educate students on different elements of Chinese culture.
More focus on written skills.
Strengths: well-organized, good structure for learning. Weaknesses: very few!

Strengths: 

The teachers. They really do care about us and decreasing stress during what has been a tumultuous year and it shows, from the meditation exercises, to the thoughtful re-cancelling of some of our final assignments. They even respected the break day by rescheduling the oral exam. 

Weaknesses: 

Some small pet peeves: dialogue homeworks for each lesson are assigned often before the second part of the lesson is assigned (i.e. during the first part), and this dialogue almost always has vocab that we dont learn until the second part (see Dialogue 11 as an example). It'd be nice if some of the dialogues focused solely on the first part vocab, and others focused on the second part vocab.
Remote language classes are difficult and I had a hard time responding to cold-calling. Breakout rooms were a strength.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very good discussions considering over zoom
almost all succeeded, we just did not get any practice with writing characters

When they gave us the text on the slides to read instead of expecting us to recite it from memory, it made the class much less stressful. Although, I feel like reciting it from memory does make us learn it better, as tough as it is. 

Also, allowing us to pre-record the oral presentations took a LOT of stress off of students, especially because sometimes our internet connections were bad. Ditto for the final video presentation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Don't give up on chinese
If they are interested in learning more Chinese language, certainly.
yes if you are on the chinese track!
Yes, the teachers really care about the students and this is an effective way to continue learning Chinese at Yale.

Yes! As with other Chinese courses, this course is well taught and engaging. It does require a bit more time than a typical class (especially if you really want to commit the new words/phrases to long term memory)  but its worth it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
I also had a weekly virtual tutorial class.
